title: 104_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996". Judicial review is addressed in the Act. Section 611 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow small entities to petition for judicial review of final rules that were certified to have no significant economic impact or had a regulatory flexibility analysis prepared. A court with jurisdiction over rule compliance can review the certification or analysis. The provision allows small entities to petition for judicial review of final rules certified to have no significant economic impact. The court can review the certification or analysis, and affected small entities can file a petition within one year of the analysis being made public. The court may order the agency to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis if the certification was found to be arbitrary, capricious, or not in accordance with the law. If the agency fails to take corrective action within 90 days, the court can intervene. The court may order the agency to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis or take corrective action within a specified period. If the agency fails to comply, the court can stay the rule or grant appropriate relief, considering the rule of prejudicial error. Any regulatory flexibility analysis for a rule is part of the record for judicial review. This section does not prevent judicial review of other required impact statements or analyses under different laws. The amendment allows judicial review of impact statements required by other laws. It applies to final agency rules issued after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. RULES COMMENTED ON BY SBA CHIEF COUNSEL FOR ADVOCACY. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to require agencies to transmit proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. Section 603 requires agencies to send proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy. The Chief Counsel may provide a written statement on the rule's impact on small entities, which the agency must publish in the Federal Register along with their response. The Federal Register must include agencies' responses to statements on proposed rules, with a special rule exempting certain rules related to monetary policy or safety of depository institutions. Section 603(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions in accordance with section 612(d). Congress believes that the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration should have the ability to appear as amicus curiae in court cases reviewing rules.
